Author: Rocket Scientist
Review:
The western terminal of the Keifuku Electric Railway.  The station is nice, there are plenty of food stalls (and all the food we tried was wonderful), and the train is actually a streetcar in a couple spots - reminded me a little of my hometown of New Orleans.

Location is terrific, Arashiyama is one of the most beautiful, scenic spots in Kyoto with several old temples and the bamboo forest - I recommend a visit via the Keifuku line and a stop at Arashiyama Station.

Author: Iqbal Hariadi
Review: Visit this station during winter (January 2018). The station is small but you can buy some Kyoto foods around the station. During winter, they also exhibit lights in the night which make the place so beautiful and instagrammable

Author: hanif muttaqin
Review:
If you want to go to arashiyama bamboo forest the option is by bus and train. If you go by train and drop in this station you just have to walk about 5 minutes to get arashiyama bamboo forest. And if you want rent a bicycle you can find in the front of station. The price is reasonable.

It's small station but has very great view. It has a mini sakura park inside. And you can enjoy foot bath here, free.

When night you can enjoy the light of kimono. Very beautiful station of Japan.

Review: Great station which has its own foot onset. Tram was a brilliant way to get around this area especially with the day pass for just 500 yen

Review:
Tiny station at the end of the line with two platforms and trains have just one carriage! However there are restrooms, lots of snack shops, a 7-11, and a restaurant. Bins are located by the platform but can be hard to find. Snacks were delicious and reasonably priced.

Turn right when you exit and then left soon after to enter the temple and then the bamboo forest

Because it is a flat fare, when you get on a train with an IC, you don't need to do anything and touch it only when you get off.

Author: È≠îÊ≥ïÂ∞ëÂ•≥„Åï„Åè„Çâ
Review:
It is the terminal station of Randen Arashiyama Main Line.
Arashiyama's sightseeing spots spread around the station. It is the main station for sightseeing in Arashiyama, and when it is simply called "Arashiyama", it often refers to the area around this station.

There are other train stations that call themselves Arashiyama, but Hankyu Arashiyama Station is about a 10-minute walk across the famous Togetsukyo Bridge, and Saga-Arashiyama Station on the JR Sanin Main Line is not impossible to walk from, but next to it. It is closer from Randen Saga Station.

There are shops selling souvenirs and sweets not only in the surrounding area but also in the station itself, and you can feel the atmosphere of a tourist destination.

On the other hand, the station itself is a manned station, but it is unmanned early in the morning and at night when it is not suitable for sightseeing. The fare is flat and you pay on the train, so there is no problem if you just want to get on the bus, but if you want to purchase a free ticket, be careful.

Author: „ÉÑ„ÉÉ„Ç≠„Éº

Review:

You can't buy souvenirs, but it's fun to take a walk to Togetsukyo Bridge, which flows with a roaring roar.

Author: ÂæíÁÑ∂ËÖêÂ•≥Â≠ê
Review:
Nicknamed [Randen], it is the starting and ending station of the Keifuku Electric Railway, Arashiyama Main Line.
In collaboration with various works (animation, manga, novels, etc.), there are collaboration menus at shops in the station premises.
There is an ATM and a convenience store.
Beer garden only in summer.
There are places where you can take pictures, and there is also a footbath (for a fee).

It is the closest station to Togetsukyo.
Straight to Main Street...

There are toilets and coin lockers.

Author: Darren Broderick

Author: M.
Review: The Randen Light Rail Line takes approximately 40 minutes to the Kitanohakubaicho terminus. Take advantage of this pretty little line that winds through town to slow down and admire the little houses.

Author: K Yeo
Review:
We took the tram from Sai station to arrive at Arashiyama Station. This is one of the closest stations from the Bamboo forest. The tram was more packed at Sai station. If you want, you can take the tram from an earlier station than Sai. You pay when you alight the tram. The tram is also quite slow but Google maps recommended this route from Osaka so we just took it. It was a nice experience compared with a regular train.

The Arashiyama station is a small station with access to the Kimono Forest, and a foot bath. We had time to take nice videos and photos in the morning before 10am with the kimono cloth displays. In the late afternoon when we left, the station was extremely crowded. There were some food stalls selling yakitori, takoyaki and other snacks.

Author: w oppa.
Review:
This area of ‚Äã‚ÄãArashiyama Park is really visited by so many people every season.....
But the environment is really beautiful/comfortable....worth visiting!!!!!
But be careful if you come by car...
There is a long-term shortage of parking spaces... Most parking lots start at 1,000 yen!!!!

Author: Grace Ooi
Review:
It was an experience to travel in a traim, the Arashiyama station has its unique iconic fabric lamps lined up, they are beautiful when it is light on.

Love the serenity of the whole place, a surprise to me to see Rirakuma shop here with the dessert and snacks, so adorable!

There are kimono rental shops just near by, if you are interested, suggest to wear kimono to walk in this beautiful bamboo forest.
Another one is the rickshaw, saw many people wearing the kimono and ride on the rickshaw, I saw a rickshaw puller who did photo shooting for his clients, the way he took photo can easily know he is not just a rickshaw puller but a professional one as a photographer too!

Author: Vgs photos
Review: Flat rate at 220yen took a tram to here to my next destination. Did get pretty packed but it was such a unique experience. Felt like I was back in the old days.

Author: koji
Review:
On May 28th (Sunday), I used it for a bicycle trip from Shijo Omiya. Of course, it's the first station, so you can sit down, but it's full immediately.
After all, in Kyoto city, it's a nuisance to other customers.
But it was atmospheric and I enjoyed it.

Author: Leo H.
Review:
I love this station. Upon arriving here, you can stow away your luggage in the coin lockers and explore Arashiyama from there. There are plenty of shops in this station, and you can never run out of things to eat or souvenirs to buy. They have shop for different kinds of sake, and a shop selling sweet potato.
The public toilet is a bit small so it can get cramped fast.
The whole station has a bamboo theme to it, and there are plenty of seatings to go around.
Right outside is a bike rental, and a rickshaw rental for your convenience.
It's still open in the middle of the night, even after the last train and all the stores are closed to make way for the Kimono forest exhibit
